status.title: Privacy Status
status.subtitle: My journey to digital privacy and the alternatives I use

categories.name: Operating System
categories.description: Debloated Windows installation that does not communicate any data to Microsoft, ensuring maximum privacy on the workstation.
categories.considerationsText: See why Ubuntu is under consideration

items.name: Chrome/Edge
items.description: Major browsers from Google and Microsoft track browsing activity and collect user data for advertising and analytics.

items.name: Brave
items.description: Privacy-focused browser that blocks trackers and ads by default.

items.name: Google Search
items.description: Google Search tracks search queries, personalizes results based on user profile, and stores search history for advertising purposes.

items.name: DuckDuckGo
items.description: Privacy-focused search engine that doesn't track users or store personal information.

items.name: No central provider
items.description: Relying on third-party platforms for app access can expose usage patterns and personal data.

items.name: pathvoid.com
items.description: Self-hosted domain for unified, private access to all apps.

items.name: Gmail
items.description: Google scans email content and metadata for advertising and profiling purposes.

items.name: Proton Mail
items.description: End-to-end encrypted email for secure communication.

items.name: Google Calendar
items.description: Google Calendar events and usage data are analyzed for integration with other Google services and advertising.

items.name: Proton Calendar
items.description: Private calendar for organizing schedules.

items.name: Google Drive
items.description: Google Drive files and activity are indexed and may be used for data mining and integration with other Google products.

items.name: Proton Drive
items.description: Encrypted cloud storage for files and documents.

items.name: Google Docs
items.description: Google Docs content is processed and stored on Google servers, subject to data analysis and integration with other services.

items.name: Proton Docs
items.description: Secure, private alternative to Google Docs.

items.name: Google Password Manager
items.description: Google Password Manager stores credentials in the Google ecosystem, which may be accessed or analyzed by Google services.

items.name: Proton Pass
items.description: Privacy-first password manager for credentials.

considerations.title: Under Consideration
considerations.subtitle: Technologies and changes being evaluated, with their current challenges.

items.name: Moving to Ubuntu
items.description: Considering switching the main operating system to Ubuntu for improved privacy and open-source benefits.
items.challenge: Previous attempts showed that new games are not fully supported, with significant FPS loss. GPU passthrough is under consideration, but would require a second GPU.

items.name: YouTube Usage
items.description: YouTube remains a major platform for video content, but requires a Google login for subscriptions and recommendations.
items.challenge: Using an email alias could help, but migration from Gmail is still in progress. For better privacy, browser containerization is under consideration, but requires further research and setup.

items.name: Personal Server Infrastructure
items.description: Evaluating setting up a personal server to self-host most services and applications, reducing dependency on third-party cloud providers.
items.challenge: Requires significant technical knowledge, ongoing maintenance, security considerations, and reliable internet connection. Initial hardware investment and energy costs.

items.name: Secure File Transfer
items.description: Considering tools like Wormhole, OnionShare, or Magic Wormhole for ephemeral, encrypted file sharing.

items.name: Remote Access & Remote Desktop Privacy
items.description: Exploring Tailscale or self-hosted WireGuard to replace TeamViewer or Google Remote Desktop.

items.name: AI (Self-hosted)
items.description: Considering hosting a personal AI instance for privacy and control, possibly using Olama.
items.challenge: Requires significant hardware resources and setup. Research needed for best open-source models and secure deployment.

items.name: De-Google Android Mobile
items.description: Evaluating switching to a de-Googled mobile OS like GrapheneOS, CalyxOS, or /e/OS to remove Google services from mobile devices.
items.challenge: Banking apps and push notifications may not work reliably; setup complexity is higher.

items.name: Social Media Alternatives
items.description: Evaluating privacy-focused social media alternatives like Mastodon (Twitter alternative), Pixelfed (Instagram alternative), and other decentralized platforms.
items.challenge: Smaller user base means less content and engagement; friends and family may not migrate; requires finding the right instances/servers.

items.name: Self-Hosted Media Streaming
items.description: Evaluating self-hosted media streaming solutions like Jellyfin or Plex to replace commercial streaming services and regain control over media consumption.
items.challenge: Requires significant storage space and bandwidth; initial setup and media organization can be time-consuming; legal considerations for media acquisition.
